abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Sixth Education Project
            for Ethiopia were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory,
            project sustainability was likely, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was deficient. Some
            lessons learned included: the time projected for physical
            construction should be realistic, and should take into
            account factors such as weather, natural calamities and
            availability of construction materials. Apart from security
            problems, it was known that the Project Management Office
            (PMO) was also involved in other projects financed by other
            donors and could hardly comply with the timing established.
            The Government's financial obligations and the
            deterioration of the economy were not properly evaluated.
            Discussing Government priorities in assigning funds is
            essential. It might be necessary to adjust the share of
            Government's contribution, and even revise the project
            scope. Procurement and import regulations both were a
            serious handicap for the project. Implementation started
            moving when Government decided to make local regulations
            more flexible. The Bank's direct site supervision and
            monitoring of the implementation process is a normal
            procedure. It should be waived only when the successive
            supervision missions are confident that they can be made
            responsive for their supervision work and would remain
            accountable for their reports.
